entry.title: Notes: An Introduction to Hypothesis Testing
entry.content:
The basic idea

Hypothesis testing is like a “probability” version of proof by contradiction. It’s based on the principle of small probability (we’re assuming that a small probability event will not occur in an experiment). When we do hypothesis testing, we usually first state a hypothesis about the population that contradicts our expected result, then use sample data to construct a test statistic, check if the small probability event occurs, and test to what extent we can say that the hypothesis holds.

Some concepts

Two types of hypotheses

  1. Null hypothesis (H0H_0H0​): a claim about the population that contradicts our desired result. We assume that H0H_0H0​ is true until we reject it. It usually uses symbols ===,≤\le≤, or ≥\ge≥.
  2. Alternative hypothesis (H1H_1H1​): the complimentary of H0H_0H0​. It usually uses symbols ≠\ne​=,>>>, or <<<.

Two types of errors

  1. Type Ⅰ error (α\alphaα error): the error that we reject H0H_0H0​, but H0H_0H0​ is true.
  2. Type Ⅱ error (β\betaβ error): the error that we fail to reject H0H_0H0​, but H0H_0H0​ is false.

The probability of different cases:

H0H_0H0​ is trueH0H_0H0​ is false
reject H0H_0H0​α\alphaα (type Ⅰ error)1−α1-\alpha1−α (correct decision)
fail to reject H0H_0H0​1−β1-\beta1−β (correct decision)β\betaβ (type Ⅱ error)

We can’t reduce both α\alphaα and β\betaβ (two probabilities) at the same time without increasing the sample size, so we should control the one that will cause a more serious consequence. In practice, people usually set a significant level α\alphaα for the type Ⅰ error, and by doing this it means that “first I have to control the chance of making a type Ⅰ error under some level (say 5%5\%5%), and then try to reduce the chance of making a type Ⅱ error, but I can’t quantify anything for the latter part.” Accordingly, we’ll consider the result that we hate, or that will cause more damage, as our null hypothesis, so at least we can use numbers to describe the chance of a bad consequence, and this is also why hypothesis testing is like proof by contradiction. Here are two unstrict examples of H0H_0H0​ (take α=5%\alpha=5\%α=5%):

  1. H0H_0H0​: the medicine is poisonous. Hence when rejecting H0H_0H0​, we can claim that the probability that “it’s poisonous but we think it’s not and take the medicine” is less than 5%5\%5%.
  2. H0H_0H0​: the new design of the app can’t bring more customers. Hence when rejecting H0H_0H0​, we can claim that there is only less than 5%5\%5% chance that the new design is useless.

Two types of tests

  1. One-tailed test: If H0H_0H0​ has the form μ=μ0\mu=\mu_0μ=μ0​.
  2. Two-tailed test: If H0H_0H0​ has the form μ≥μ0\mu\ge\mu_0μ≥μ0​ or μ≤μ0\mu\le\mu_0μ≤μ0​.

Test statistic

A test statistic is a random variable calculated from sample data. In hypothesis testing, we assume that this random variable follows some appropriate distribution. By considering its probability density function and the observed value we get, we can tell if a small probability event occurs and then decide whether we should reject H0H_0H0​ or not.

Significant level and critical value

The significant level is the value we set for α\alphaα, or equivalently it’s the bound we set for the chance of making a type Ⅰ error. The critical value is the value of the test statistic which corresponds to a given significant level.

PPP-value

We can consider the ppp-value as the probability of getting the observed value of the test statistic that we choose.

Rejection region

The rejection region is an area of the graph of the probability density function where we should reject H0H_0H0​. It’s determined by the test statistic and the significant level.

The logic of hypothesis testing

  1. State the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis.
  2. Select and calculate the test statistic according to the problem.
  3. Set a significant level α\alphaα and calculate the ppp-value.
  4. By comparing two values in step 3 to decide whether we reject (if p<αp<\alphap<α) or fail to reject (if p>αp>\alphap>α) the null hypothesis.

When p>αp>\alphap>α we can’t say that we “accept” H0H_0H0​ since we have assumed that H0H_0H0​ is true and are trying to see if we can reject it.

Selection and calculation of the test statistic

The selection of the test statistic:

flowchart TD    A{How many populations?} -->|One population| B1{What do we test?}    A -->|Two populations| B2{What do we test?}    B1 -->|Mean| C1{Small sample size?}    C1 -->|Yes| E1{Unknown population standard deviation?}    C1 -->|No| D2[2/ Z-test]    E1 -->|Yes| D1[1/ T-test]    E1 -->|No| D2[2/ Z-test]    B1 -->|Proportion| D3[3/ Z-test]    B1 -->|Variance| D4[4/ Chi-squared test]    B2 -->|Mean| C2{Small sample size?}    C2 -->|Yes| E2{Unknown population standard deviation?}    C2 -->|No| D6[6/ Z-test]    E2 -->|Yes| D5[5/ T-test]    E2 -->|No| D6[6/ Z-test]    B2 -->|Proportion| D7[7/ Z-test]    B2 -->|Variance| D8[8/ F-test]

The calculation of the test statistic (corresponding to the flowchart above):

  1. t=xˉ−μ0s/nt=\frac{\bar{x}-\mu_0}{s/\sqrt{n}}t=s/n​xˉ−μ0​​
  2. z=xˉ−μ0σ/nz=\frac{\bar{x}-\mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}z=σ/n​xˉ−μ0​​ if the population standard deviation σ\sigmaσ is known, or z=xˉ−μ0s/nz=\frac{\bar{x}-\mu_0}{s/\sqrt{n}}z=s/n​xˉ−μ0​​ if the population standard deviation σ\sigmaσ is unknown.
  3. z=p−π0π0(1−π0)/nz=\frac{p-\pi_0}{\sqrt{\pi_0(1-\pi_0)/n}}z=π0​(1−π0​)/n​p−π0​​
  4. χ2=(n−1)s2σ2\chi^2=\frac{(n-1)s^2}{\sigma^2}χ2=σ2(n−1)s2​
  5. t=(xˉ1−xˉ2)−(μ1−μ2)sp1n1+1n2t=\frac{(\bar{x}_1-\bar{x}_2)-(\mu_1-\mu_2)}{s_p\sqrt{\frac{1}{n_1}+\frac{1}{n_2}}}t=sp​n1​1​+n2​1​​(xˉ1​−xˉ2​)−(μ1​−μ2​)​ where sp2=(n1−1)s12+(n2−2)s22n1+n2−2s_p^2=\frac{(n_1-1)s_1^2+(n_2-2)s_2^2}{n_1+n_2-2}sp2​=n1​+n2​−2(n1​−1)s12​+(n2​−2)s22​​ if σ12=σ22\sigma_1^2=\sigma_2^2σ12​=σ22​, or t=(xˉ1−xˉ2)−(μ1−μ2)s12n1+s22n2t=\frac{(\bar{x}_1-\bar{x}_2)-(\mu_1-\mu_2)}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2}{n_1}+\frac{s_2^2}{n_2}}}t=n1​s12​​+n2​s22​​​(xˉ1​−xˉ2​)−(μ1​−μ2​)​ if we think σ12≠σ22\sigma_1^2\ne\sigma_2^2σ12​​=σ22​.
  6. z=(xˉ1−xˉ2)−(μ1−μ2)σ12n1+σ22n2z=\frac{(\bar{x}_1-\bar{x}_2)-(\mu_1-\mu_2)}{\sqrt{\frac{\sigma_1^2}{n_1}+\frac{\sigma_2^2}{n_2}}}z=n1​σ12​​+n2​σ22​​​(xˉ1​−xˉ2​)−(μ1​−μ2​)​
  7. z=p1−p2p(1−p)(1n1+1n2)z=\frac{p_1-p_2}{\sqrt{p(1-p)(\frac{1}{n_1}+\frac{1}{n_2})}}z=p(1−p)(n1​1​+n2​1​)​p1​−p2​​
  8. F=s12/σ12s22/σ22=s12s22F=\frac{s_1^2/\sigma_1^2}{s_2^2/\sigma_2^2}=\frac{s_1^2}{s_2^2}F=s22​/σ22​s12​/σ12​​=s22​s12​​ where s1≥s2s_1\ge s_2s1​≥s2​ and degrees of freedom are (n1−1,n2−2)(n_1-1,n_2-2)(n1​−1,n2​−2).

entry.title: A Simple Example of Using Gurobi to Solve An Integer Optimization Problem
entry.content:
The problem is provided by the course Math 728 SP22 at UW-Madison. The code is a part of my homework submission.

Problem description

The following is a formulation of a multiple-product lot sizing problem having III products and TTT time periods.

min∑i=1I∑t=1Thisit+∑i=1I∑t=1Tfiyit(1)s.t.si,t−1+xit=Dit+sit,i=1,…,I,t=1,…,T(2)si0=SIi, siT=SF,i=1,…,I(3)xit≤(∑k=tTDik+SF)yit,i=1,…,I,t=1,…,T(4)∑i=1Iαixit+∑i=1Iβiyit≤L,t=1,…,T(5)xit≥0,sit≥0,yit∈{0,1},i=1,…,I(6)\begin{aligned}&\text{min}&\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}h_is_{it}+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{T}f_iy_{it}&&\text{(1)}\\&\text{s.t.}&s_{i,t-1}+x_{it}=D_{it}+s_{it},\quad&i=1,\dots,I,t=1,\dots,T&\text{(2)}\\&&s_{i0}=SI_i,\: s_{iT}=SF,\quad&i=1,\dots,I&\text{(3)}\\&&x_{it}\le (\sum\limits_{k=t}^{T}D_{ik}+SF)y_{it},\quad&i=1,\dots,I,t=1,\dots,T&\text{(4)}\\&&\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_ix_{it}+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}\beta_iy_{it}\le L,\quad&t=1,\dots,T&\text{(5)}\\&&x_{it}\ge0,s_{it}\ge0,y_{it}\in \{0,1\},\quad&i=1,\dots,I&\text{(6)}\end{aligned}​mins.t.​i=1∑I​t=1∑T​hi​sit​+i=1∑I​t=1∑T​fi​yit​si,t−1​+xit​=Dit​+sit​,si0​=SIi​,siT​=SF,xit​≤(k=t∑T​Dik​+SF)yit​,i=1∑I​αi​xit​+i=1∑I​βi​yit​≤L,xit​≥0,sit​≥0,yit​∈{0,1},​i=1,…,I,t=1,…,Ti=1,…,Ii=1,…,I,t=1,…,Tt=1,…,Ti=1,…,I​(1)(2)(3)(4)(5)(6)​

Here, the variables xitx_{it}xit​ represent the amount of product iii to produce in period ttt, the binary variables yity_{it}yit​ will equal one when a set-up of product iii occurs in period ttt (which is required if xit>0x_{it}>0xit​>0), and sit represents the inventory level of product iii at time ttt. The data for the this problem are the holding costs hih_ihi​, setup costs fif_ifi​, initial inventory SIiSI_iSIi​ for each product iii, ending inventory SFSFSF (same for all products), demand DitD_{it}Dit​ for each product iii and time period ttt; capacity LLL for the machine; and required machine usage αi\alpha_iαi​ for each unit of product iii on machine kkk and required machine usage βi\beta_iβi​ if a setup of product iii is done on machine kkk in a period. The constraints (2)\text{(2)}(2) specify the inventory balance conditions and constraint (3)\text{(3)}(3) specifies the inititial and final inventory levels. The constraint (4)\text{(4)}(4) specifies that a setup must occur if production for a product type iii is done. All products must be processed on a single machine. Constraints (5)\text{(5)}(5) are the capacity constraints for the machine. The objective is to find a feasible production plan that meets the customer demands while minimizing the inventory holding costs and setup costs. (Production costs do not need to be considered because the total amount produced over time is fixed based on the demands and ending inventory requirements.) Implement and solve the model with a MIP solver of your choice.

Code

Results

entry.content:
I made this summary after studying how to create some often-used plots using Matplotlib package in Python. Some examples are originally from Veekesh Dhununjoy on Medium, and the dataset can be downloaded here.

entry.title: Skydiving
entry.content: The second before I jumped out of the plane, I was thinking “NOOO WAYYY!”
